questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

TLD badge (thermoluminescent dosimeter) is made up of Lithium fluoride or calcium sulfate doped with dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices. In India, one TLD badge has to be worn at the chest level inside the lead apron, if the apron is used. An additional wrist badge has to be worn for procedures requiring hands close to the primary beam. 

The given image shows a TLD badge.

questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The Leopold's third maneuver is also called the Pawlik’s grip. It is performed by grasping with the thumb and fingers, the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt.

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers)

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. 1st pelvic grip /Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

questions.text: The following catheter is used for?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the Swan-ganz catheter used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is also called the pulmonary artery catheter. The standard pulmonary artery catheter is 110 cm long with a 7.0 – 9.0 Fr circumference. 

Uses:

  • Measurement of pressures in right atrium, right ventricle and pulmonary artery
  • Indirect measurement of left atrial pressure through pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Oxygen saturation- pulmonary samples to rule out left-right shunt
  • Monitoring left ventricle filling pressure
  • Differentiate cardiogenic from non cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.text: What type of skull fracture is shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a gutter fracture of the skull.

It is a furrow in the outer table of the skull, ordinarily the result of a glancing blow by a missile from a rifled firearm. These are frequently accompanied with comminuted depressed fractures of inner table of the skull.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Propylthiouracil can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is indicated in the management of hyperthyroidism.

Other options

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptor blockers are fetopathic and can cause fetal growth retardation and hypoplasia of organs. 

Statins can cause Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is normal peristalsis not seen?
questions.solution:
Achalasia cardia does not show normal peristalsis.

Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows:

  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation
  • Aperistalsis of the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure

Diffuse esophageal spasm is characterized by simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of the esophagus. The contractions are spontaneous and may be of abnormally high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration. Intermittent normal peristalsis is seen.

Nutcracker esophagus is characterized by high amplitude (≥180 mmHg) contractions with an increased mean duration. The peristaltic sequence is normal.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter is characterized by elevated LES pressure (≥26 mmHg). Normal peristalsis is seen in the body of the esophagus.

Esophageal carcinoma will not have any issues with the motility or peristalsis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similar pain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable.  Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, the next best step is to explore surgically.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting. Testis seems high in the scrotum and the twisted cord can sometimes be palpated.

Signs seen on torsion of the testis are:

  • Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle due to twisting of the spermatic cord causes the affected testis to be positioned higher than the normal testis.
  • Angell’s sign: The testis on the normal side lies horizontally because of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.
  • Cremastic reflex: Absent on the side of the affected testis

Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, but the false positives are high and hence it is not routinely recommended. The typical window of opportunity for surgical intervention and testicular salvage is 6 hours from onset of pain.

Testicular torsion is a clinical diagnosis and an emergency, therefore no time is wasted in performing the other investigations.

questions.text: A 30 -year-old male  with a history of taking medications for rheumatoid arthritis, now presents with obesity, short stature, round face, and his abdominal findings was as in the picture below. On examination, pulse rate is 96/minute, blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
The probable cause in this case is Cushing's syndrome.

History of Rheumatoid arthritis suggests that patient had been on exogenous steroids for long term management of rheumatoid arthritis.

The presenting features with a round face (moon facies), short stature, along with obesity and purple skin striae suggest a diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome and the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome is prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids. 

Cushing's syndrome is characterized by clinical features that result from chronic exposure of excess glucocorticoids that can be due to

  • Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids (Iatrogenic: Most common cause of Cushing's syndrome) 
  • Excess endogenous cortisol secretion:
    • In children <7 years: Most often by a functioning adrenocortical tumor
    • In children >7 years: Most often by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)–producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease)

Important clinical features 

  • Obesity or weight gain (most common)
  • Moon facies
  • Purple skin striae
  • Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls)
  • Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girls
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Sepsis

Diagnosis:

Step 1: Confirm the diagnosis

The following investigations are used to establish an initial diagnosis of endogenous Cushing's syndrome as per the clinical guidelines of the endocrine society.

  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol (increased 3x above normal), used as a screening test.
  • Midnight salivary cortisol ( >5nmol/L)
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression (plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8-9 AM after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 PM)

Step 2: Identify the source

1.This is done by measuring plasma ACTH level

  • If ACTH low-primary cause of hypercortisolism  (suppressed levels of ACTH due to negative feedback)
  • If ACTH high-secondary cause of hypercortisolism(may be due to a pituitary pathology, commonly a microadenoma or an ectopic source of ACTH production by a tumour such as a small cell lung cancer.)

2.Standard 2-day (high dose) dexamethasone suppression test:

  • Serum cortisol level and/or 24-hour urinary free cortisol is measured as a baseline, and then dexamethasone 2 mg orally is taken every 6 hours for 48 hours; urine for free cortisol is collected during the test and serum cortisol is checked 6 hours after the last dose. The suppression of cortisol secretion to >50 % of the baseline is considered positive and indicative of Cushing's disease.

If ACTH is elevated but lack of suppression in high dose dexamethasone suppression test is seen, an ectopic source must be looked for, by imaging studies like CT of the thorax and abdomen to detect the presence of any tumors.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Screening/Confirmatory Test for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

  • 24-h urinary free cortisol excretion increased above normal (3x)
  • Dexamethasone overnight test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8–9 a.m. after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 p.m.
  • Midnight plasma cortisol >130 nmol/L
  • Midnight salivary cortisol >5 nmol/L
  • Low dose Dexamethasone test – Best initial test
    • Plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg dexamethasone q6h for 2 days

If a number of these tests are positive then a diagnosis of Cushing’s syndrome is confirmed.

Related Pearl: Side effects of Corticosteroids: mnemonic "CORTICOSTEROIDS"

The mnemonic is "CORTICOSTEROIDS"

C - Cushing’s syndrome

O - Osteoporosis

R - Retardation of growth

T - Thin skin and easy bruisability

I - Infections and immunosuppression

C - Cataract

O - Oedema

S - Suppression of HPA axis

T - Thinning and ulceration of gastric mucosa

E - Emotional disturbance

R - Rise in BP

O - Others fatal abnormalities like hypokalemia

I - Increase in hair growth (hirsutism)

D - Diabetes mellitus precipitation

S - Striae

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by​ the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

Trichuris trichiura are barrel-shaped, thick-shelled, and have a pair of polar plugs at each end. They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

It causes rectal prolapse in children (characteristic feature) because the rectum loses its internal support as the worms bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles; also, there is rectal edema because of the infection. All these factors finally lead to rectal prolapse.Trichuriasis is caused by the T. trichura (whipworm), which inhabits the cecum and ascending colon.

Clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth and developmental defects.

Diagnosis:

Fecal smears showing barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichura. The eggs of Trichuris trichura does not have a terminal spine. They are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends. 

Treatment: Albendazole is the drug of choice (400 mg, orally, for 3 days; for all ages)

The image of egg of trichuris trichura is given below:

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with dysphagia and regurgitation. Barium swallow showed the following picture. Weakness of which of the following muscles predisposes to the given condition​?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a pulsion diverticulum on the barium swallow is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It originates through Killian's dehiscence, which is a site of weakness present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts:

  1. Upper part - thyropharyngeus, made of oblique fibres.
  2. Lower part - cricopharyngeus, made of transverse fibres.

Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the circular muscle of the oesophagus.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress and drooling of saliva. Nasogastric tube cannot be passed to the stomach. There is history of maternal polyhydramnios. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of esophageal atresia with or without TEF.  In the setting of early-onset respiratory distress, the inability to pass a nasogastric or orogastric tube in the newborn suggests EA.

Features:

  • Esophageal atresia (EA) is the most common congenital anomaly of the esophagus. It is often associated with single umbilical artery.
  • >90% of babies with EA have an associated tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).
  • In the most common form of EA, the upper esophagus ends in a blind pouch and the TEF is connected to the distal esophagus.

CXR of pure EA can manifest as an airless scaphoid abdomen.

CXR showing a coiled feeding tube in the esophageal pouch and an air-distended stomach, indicating the presence of a coexisting TEF.

Other options:

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia:

Presents with respiratory distress in the neonatal period, scaphoid abdomen and bowel sounds which are present in the chest wall.
The tip of NG tube will be in the stomach in the thoracic cavity.
CXR shows: shows a stomach, nasogastric tube, and small bowel contents in the thoracic cavity, consistent with a CDH.

Acute Gastric Volvulus presents with classic symptoms (Borchardt triad) which include:

  • Unproductive retching (here patient presents with drooling NOT retching)
  • Localised epigastric distension
  • Inability to pass NG tube

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of Niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

The lesion in the neck is characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal's collar or Casal's necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

questions.text: A 30-day-old infant is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. He has a large and hazy cornea in both eyes. His lacrimal system is normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)

It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Several genes have been implicated, prominently CYP1B1.

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely physiological change in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Decrease in peripheral vascular resistance is a physiologial change in pregnancy. 

Parameters increasing in pregnancy:

  • Cardiac output
  • Stroke volume
  • Heart rate

Parameters decreasing in pregnancy:

  • Peripheral vascular resistance (due to smooth muscle relaxation by progesterone)
  • Both diastolic BP and systolic BP (decrease in DBP > SBP)
  • Mean arterial BP
  • Artery venous O2 gradient

Late pregnancy was associated with decreased systemic vascular and pulmonary vascular resistance both decreased significantly, as did colloid osmotic pressure.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: The preparation shown below is used for the diagnosis of  ________
questions.solution:
Hanging drop preparation is used for diagnosis of trichomniasis.

  • Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan, actively mo­tile and slightly larger than a leucocyte and is anaerobic.
  • A trichomonas has four anterior flagella and one posterior flagella, and they move along the mucous membrane.
  • The posterior flagella are respon­sible for motility.

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, of which the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images.

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

Structure
T1 image
T2 image
Grey matter
Darker
 Lighter
White matter
 Lighter  Darker
CSF/ Fluids
Dark
Bright
Fat
White
Less white
Air
Dark
Dark
Cortical bone
Dark
Dark
Tendons and ligaments
Dark
Dark
Calcification
Dark
Dark
Flowing blood and hemosiderin
Dark
Dark

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of persistent headaches. A CT scan of the head reveals a brain tumour. On histopathology, psammoma bodies are seen. Based on these findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the histopathology showing a tumour with psammoma bodies is suggestive of meningioma.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors in adults, typically attached to the dura and arising from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. They can develop along any external surface of the brain or within the ventricular system, originating from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.

A major risk factor for meningiomas is prior radiation therapy to the head and neck. The most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with these tumors is the loss of chromosome 22, particularly the long arm (22q). Meningiomas are frequently seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), often occurring at multiple sites, especially alongside acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.

The tumor mass is usually encapsulated but may also grow en plaque, where it spreads in a sheetlike manner along the dura, often leading to hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone. Histologically, meningiomas may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies, a characteristic microscopic feature.

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

The histological section of meningioma showing psammoma bodies is given below:

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, choroid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

Other Options:

Option A: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes with arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen can be seen in Retinoblastoma.

Option B: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is composed of tumor cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumor contains sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin, surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives them a fried egg appearance. They contain a network of anastomosing capillaries, resembling chicken wire and also have calcifications.

Related Pearl: Psammoma Bodies

Psammoma bodies are visible in the following:

  • Meningioma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma Ovary
  • Papillary carcinoma thyroid.
  • Papillary type of renal cell carcinoma

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Halberstaedter–Prowazek bodies

 Trachoma 
Miyagawa bodies Lymphogranuloma venereum 
Levinthal–Cole–Lillie bodies Psittacosis
Leishman–Donovan bodies Kala-azar 
Negri bodies Rabies
Guarnieri bodies Vaccinia
Bollinger bodies Fowl pox
Henderson–Peterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum 
Cowdry type-A bodies Yellow fever, Herpes virus infection 
Cowdry type-B bodies Adenovirus, poliovirus
Rusell bodies Multiple myeloma 
Aschoff bodies Rheumatic fever 
Call–Exner bodies Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary 
Civatte (colloid) bodies Lichen planus 
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies Malakoplakia 
Lewy bodies Parkinson's disease 
Pappenheimer bodies Non-heme iron pigments in siderocytes 
Howell–Jolly bodies Splenectomy, Megaloblastic Anemia, Hemolytic anemia 
Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency 
Gamna–Gandy bodies Congestive splenomegaly 
Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.
Psammoma bodies Dystrophic calcification in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenoma of ovary & papillary carcinoma of thyroid, papillary type of renal cell carcinoma.
Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale 
Nissl's bodies Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons 
Mooser bodies Typhus fever
Creola bodies Asthma 
Verocay bodies Schwannoma 
Schiller–Duval bodies Endodermal sinus tumor 

Hirano bodies

  Alzheimer’s disease

Ferruginous bodies

 Asbestosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who lost his wife 3 months back complains that his intestines have become rotten. He feels that he is responsible for his wife's death and should be sent to prison. He complains of feeling low all the time and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of persistent low mood, anhedonia, guilt, and self-critical thought content along with nihilistic delusion (rotten intestine), points towards a diagnosis of major depression with psychotic features.

Differentiating features of grief and depression have been enlisted in the following table:

Grief Depression
Feelings of emptyness and loss Persistent low mood and inability to anticipate pleasure
Dysphoria comes in waves and tends to decrease in intentsity over time Low mood tends to be persistent and consistent
Associated with thoughts and reminders of deceased/loss Not tied to specific thoughts and pre-occupations
May be present along with positive emotions and humor Pervassive unhappiness and misery
Thought content associated with thoughts and memories of deceased/loss Thought content associated with self-critical and pessimistic ruminations
Self-esteem is generally preserved Worthlessness and self-loathing is common
Ideas of death focused on joining the deceased Ideas of death focused on ending life due to hopelessness

Note: Tricyclic antidepressants are considered to be the first-line drugs for psychotic depression.

questions.text: What does number 2 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote?

choices.text: Diagnosed hypertensive subjects not on treatment

questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves, which is observed in hypertension, and "number 2." denotes normotensive subjects.

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with persistent headaches over the last 1 month. Her father and paternal uncle suffered from kidney disease and both died in their 50's of a 'brain bleed'. Her blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg and had also been elevated during a previous visit. Which of the following investigations should be avoided in this patient?

choices.text: Contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen
Non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen
MR angiography of the cerebral vasculature

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). These patients usually have impaired renal function. Hence, contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) would usually be avoided due to the risk of contrast nephrotoxicity.

The following investigations are done in patients with ADPKD:

  • USG abdomen - for screening and diagnosis
  • Non-contrast CT abdomen - more sensitive and picks up cysts of smaller size
  • MR-angiography of brain - pre-symptomatic screening for intracerebral aneurysms 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Disease

Mode of inheritance

Pathologic features

Histopathology

Clinical features/Complications

ADPKD

AD

Large multicystic kidneys, liver cysts, berry aneurysms

Cysts are lined by cuboidal or flattened epithelium, may have papillary projections or polyps

Hematuria, flank pain, urinary tract infection, renal stones, hypertension

Childhood polycystic kidney disease

AR

Enlarged cystic kidneys at birth

Saccular dilation of all collecting tubules with linning of cuboidal cells

Hepatic fibrosis

Medullary sponge kidney

None

Medullary cysts

Cysts lined by cuboidal epithelium or occasionally by transitional epithelium

Hematuria, urinary tract infection, recurrent renal stones; renal function usually normal

Familial juvenile nephronopthisis

AR

Corticomedullary cysts, shrunken kidneys contracted granular surfaces,

Cysts lined by flattened or cuboidal epithelium surrounded by either inflammatory cells or fibrous tissue

Salt-wasting, polyuria, growth retardation, anemia

Adult-onset medullary cystic disease

AD

Corticomedullary cysts, shrunken kidneys

Cysts lined by flattened or cuboidal epithelium

Salt-wasting, polyuria

Multicystic renal dysplasia

None

Irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys

Cysts lined by flattened epithelium

Immature collecting ducts

Islands of undifferentiated mesenchyme, often with cartilage

Bilateral: Renal failure

Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis or atresia

Acquired renal cystic disease

None

Cystic degeneration in end-stage kidney disease

Often contain calcium oxalate crystals

Cortical and medullary renal cysts

Contain clear fluid, are lined by hyperplastic epithelium

Hemorrhage, erythrocytosis,

Neoplasia

12- to 18-fold increased risk of renal cell carcinoma

Simple renal cysts

None

Single or multiple, normal sized kidney

Single layer of cuboidal or flattened epithelium

Microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Which of the following items are disposed of in the yellow bag?
questions.solution:
Blood bags are disposed of in the yellow bag.

Gloves are disposed of in the red bag.

Sharps are disposed of in the white container.

Urine bags are disposed of in the red bag.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

The changes as per the new Biomedical waste management (amendment) rules, 2018 have been included in the above table and highlighted in green.

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of above facilities, shredding
or mutilation or combination of
sterilization and shredding. 

Microbiology, Biotechnology, Clinical Laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, Laboratory
cultures, stocks or
specimens of microorganisms,
live or
attenuated vaccines,
human and animal cell
cultures used in
research, industrial
laboratories, production
of biological, residual
toxins, dishes and
devices used for
cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/ plasma pyrolysis/ Disposal in a  secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production
and used or discarded
disinfectants.

 Disposed of by incineration or Plasma
Pyrolysis or Encapsulation in
hazardous waste treatment, storage and
disposal facility.

Waste :
Liquid waste generated
due to use of chemicals
in production of
biological and used or
discarded disinfectants,
Silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded Formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body
fluids, liquid from
laboratories and floor
washings, cleaning,
house-keeping and
disinfecting activities
etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before
mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable Contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes(without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vaccutainers with needles cut and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by -  Shredding/mutilation

And later -  Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/Road making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/Mutilation/
Encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/Sanitary landfill/Waste sharps

 

 

  Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic Body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 Note: Ash from incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: From the following epidemic curve, identify the type of epidemic depicted.
questions.solution:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image.

In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time and they occur within one incubation period of the disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: Disruption of the axon with an intact endoneurium is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Disruption of the axon with an intact endoneurium is seen in axonotmesis. There is an axonal disruption (inner axon is damaged) and loss of conductivity, with an intact outer sheath. 

Axonotmesis (axonal interruption): There is a loss of conduction, but the continuity of the nerve is maintained and the neural tubes are intact. There is disruption of the axon i.e., the continuity of the axon is broken. But the endoneurium and perineurium are intact, maintaining the continuity of the nerve. It occurs following trauma such as closed fractures and dislocations.

Distal to the lesion, Wallerian degeneration of the disrupted axon occurs, where axons disintegrate and are resorbed by phagocytes. It is then followed by axonal regeneration where numerous fine unmyelinated fibres grow from the proximal stumps to the endoneurial tubes.

Other options:

Option A- Neurapraxia is the reversible physiological nerve conduction block causing some loss of sensation and muscle power. There is spontaneous recovery after a few days or weeks. It occurs following prolonged compression, as in Saturday night palsy, and crutch palsy. Here, there is segmental demyelination but the axon is intact. Nerve conduction is slowed because of the loss of myelin. It is followed by the regeneration of the myelin.

Option B- Neurotmesis is the complete transection of the nerve trunk. It is usually associated with open wounds. The endoneurial tubes are destroyed and the scar tissue prevents the regenerating axons from entering the distal segment. The regenerating fibers mingle with proliferating Schwann cells and fibroblasts to form a neuroma at the site of injury.

Option D- Axonapraxia is a disruption to the axoplasmic flow of neurochemicals temporarily.

Related Pearl: Seddon's classification of nerve injuries

Seddon's classification includes 3 groups

  1. Neurapraxia
  2. Axonotmesis
  3. Neurotmesis

Neurapraxia:

Reversible physiologic conduction block. Occurs due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination.

E.g.,Saturday night palsy, torniquet, and crutch palsy

Axonotmesis: 

Axonal interruption. Conduction is lost but the nerve is in continuity and neural tubes are intact.

E.g.,Closed fractures and dislocations

Neurotmesis: 

Division of the nerve trunk. Endoneurial tube destruction also occurs.

E.g., Complete section of nerve in open fractures

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presented with acute ST segment elevated anterior myocardial infarction and coronary stenting was performed. During follow-up, he reported pain over his toes. On examination, coloured skin lesions were observed at both feet with tenderness as in the image. He also developed progressive deterioration in renal functions. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a classical history of atheroembolism also called cholesterol embolism or Blue toe syndrome.

Key points in the history:

  • Patient with ST elevation myocardial infarction presenting with clinical features of limb ischemia (Cyanotic discoloration of the toes with pain and tenderness) following an intraarterial procedure (angioplasty).

Atheroembolism:

  • Atheroembolism is a condition in which multiple small deposits of fibrin, platelets, and cholesterol debris embolize from proximal atherosclerotic lesions or aneurysmal sites.
  • Large protruding aortic atheromas are a source of emboli that may lead to limb ischemia, as well as stroke and renal insufficiency.
  • Atheroembolism may occur after intraarterial procedures like angioplasty (percutaneous coronary intervention).
  • Since atheroemboli to limbs tend to lodge in the small vessels of the muscle and skin and may not occlude the large vessels, distal pulses usually remain palpable.
  • Patients complain of acute pain and tenderness at the site of embolization.
  • Digital vascular occlusion may result in ischemia and the "blue toe" syndrome; digital necrosis and gangrene may develop.
  • Localized areas of tenderness, pallor, and livedo reticularis occur at sites of emboli.
  • Skin or muscle biopsy may demonstrate cholesterol crystals.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS).

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball
  • Nasal polyps
  • Mucocele 
  • Control of epistaxis 
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Barotrauma sinusitis (pain in the face during descent in aircraft or descent whilst scuba diving)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with severe pancreatitis. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and severe hypoxia. Below is the CXR obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of severe pancreatitis and the chest X-ray findings of B/L diffuse alveolar opacities are suggestive of ARDS.

Severe pancreatitis gives rise to inflammatory processes and endothelial damage that results in ARDS. 

CXR features in ARDS:

  • Early findings include normal or diffuse alveolar opacities (consolidation), which are often bilateral and which obscure the pulmonary vascular markings.
  • Later, these opacities progress to more extensive consolidation that is diffuse.

Prolonged bed rest increases the risk of venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. However, the CXR shows diffuse alveolar opacities making the diagnosis of ARDS more likely.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia usually appears after 48 hours of admission. Areas of consolidation in unilateral or bilateral lung fields may be seen depending on severity. 

Left ventricular failure is an important differential diagnosis for ARDS. However, the patient's history of acute pancreatitis makes the diagnosis of ARDS more likely.

questions.text: Insulin acts on glucose metabolism by______

choices.text: ↓ permeability of glucose across cell membrane
↑ reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules

questions.solution:
Insulin stimulates the entry of glucose into cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane.

This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues.

Related Pearl: Glucose Transporters

 

Function

Major sites of expression

Secondary active transport

(Na + -glucose cotransport)

    

SGLT 1

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Absorption of glucose

Renal tubules

Facilitated diffusion

    

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Fructose transport

Jejunum, sperm

questions.text: Identify the type of flap.
questions.solution:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. In a free flap the blood supply is isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using micosurgery at the new site. Other eg: DIEP (Deep inferior epigastric perforators) flap, free fibular flap

  • A random flap include three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters.Eg:V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg or rhomboid flap.
  • Axial flap is much longer and is based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus dorsi flap,TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap
  • Islanded flap are those in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.

Note:

Flap defines the tongue of tissue; pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the vascular supply.

Skin-bearing flaps are classified according to three basic characteristics—

  • Composition: refers to the tissue contained within the flap, such as cutaneous, musculocutaneous, fasciocutaneous etc
  • Method of movement:
    • Local transfer, eg. advancement or rotation flaps
    • Distant transfer, eg. pedicle flaps from the abdomen to the perineum or micro-vascular free flaps.
  • Blood supply
    • Musculocutaneous arteries travel perpendicularly through muscle to the overlying skin.
    • Septocutaneous arteries travel with intermuscular fascial septa to supply the overlying skin.

questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively. 

Hitchhiker thumb deformity is a musculoskeletal manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis. It is seen on the thumb. The deformity has flexion at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint hyperextension at the interphalangeal (IP) joint

 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The image is of Atopic dermatosis.

Atopic dermatosis is a relapsing inflammatory skin disorder that is common in infancy and presents differently in different age groups. It is characterized by pruritus leading to lichenification.

Clinical features:

  • In infants: The lesions most frequently start on the face, and then, the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows are involved.
  • In Children: Dry, scaly, pruritic, excoriated papules and plaques in the flexural areas and neck.
  • In adults: Lichenification and dry, fissured skin in a flexural distribution.
